title: Thursday, 30th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hiya

PM11:01am

New Brexit era etc

PM11:01am

Ed Conway Tweeted this chart earlier

11:01 am
PM11:01am

PM11:02am

Regional GDP per capita in EU countries. UK has the biggest gap between its regions.

PM11:02am

By some margin

11:02 am
PM11:02am

I wasnt sure where that was from

PM11:02am

So went looking

PM11:02am

Derived from here http://ec.europa.e..._at_regional_level

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Ah, here's the eurostat version

PM11:02am

PM11:03am

Sorry -- not rendering

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Reason for Brexit in one chart?

PM11:04am

Dunno

11:03 am
PM11:04am

That's maybe far too simplisitic

PM11:04am

But its worth remembering that it was Labour policy that produced the gap

BE11:04am

Really?

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Blair welcoming billionaires to the UK with tax breaks

PM11:04am

Idea was trickle down wealth

PM11:05am

Instead we got trickle down anger

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hm. There are any number of reasons why London's a filthy core-collapse supernova dragging capital out of the nicer places. I'm a bit cautious to blame Blair solely.

PM11:05am

Ok, add Gordon Brown in as well then

BE11:05am

Fine.

11:05 am
undefined
PM11:05am

Markets!

PM11:05am

Are flat Omg smile

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Yes, markets!

BE11:06am

Are flat.

BE11:06am

We have retail, I guess, and lots of it.

11:06 am
PM11:07am

This is true

PM11:07am

Where do we start

BE11:07am

Since you open with Brexit, might as well continue with the theme.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Because UBS has one of those Evidence Lab thingmies out.

PM11:08am

On consumer sentiment

BE11:08am

Yup. The key finding is that consumer confidence (as measured by spending intentions) seems to have dropped off sharply.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

And it's dropped off among the olds.

PM11:08am

Is this the UK?

BE11:09am

Indeed it is. And it's an obvious argument to make that those who voted for Brexit -- the olds -- seem to be worried most about its effect. The survey doesn't actually say that, but it's an extrapolation.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

UBS finds a "substantial shift down in terms of households' views about the outlook, especially in older consumers"

PM11:10am

I'm not surprised. Really seeing price hikes in things you'd like to actually buy -- korna affect showing through.

PM11:10am

I was in a steak restaurant yesterday and the cheapest red on the wine list was 46 quid.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Guessing you were in Hawksmoor, not Angus Steak House. I'm not sure we can class that as typical.

PM11:11am

28 50

PM11:11am

But yes

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Also note you're calling it "Korna". It's gone from being a third-rank currency to a mid-nineties nu-metal band.

BE11:11am

Anyway! Here's a chart.

BE11:11am

11:11 am
BE11:11am

And here are two more charts.

BE11:11am

BE11:12am

Also, have another chart.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

BE11:12am

So people expect to spend more at Zara, Asos and Primark

BE11:12am

And less at M&S, Next and Debenhams

11:12 am
BE11:12am

(Also less at Amazon which, interestingly enough, is going nowhere in apparel despite throwing a lot of cash and effort at the side over the past year.)

PM11:12am

Goodness, this is quite depressing

BE11:13am

But is it depression that's already priced in? Maybe.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

It is hard to be incrementally bearish on UK retail sector at this stage given the de-rating to c.12x Cal 17 PE but we do not think the market is pricing in the annualisation of the weak consumer into 2018. We think the sector is unlikely to re-rate until earnings have been rebased for 2018. We are seeing downgrades on each guidance release for the year ahead and earnings capitulation has not yet been reached

BE11:13am

(@Flaneur: a brass plate with a thousand desks behind it? K.)

BE11:13am

All of which leads us to M&S.

11:13 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 330.00, down 5.5 (-1.64%), High: 335.00, Low: 329.40, Volume: 2.47m
BE11:14am

Because it's for old people to buy pants and expensive ready meals. The outlook for old-people pants is poor and the expensive ready meals won't be able to carry it.

BE11:14am

UBS again .....

11:14 am
BE11:14am

While we are already cautious on M&S non-food LFL, this seems to take away any upside risk and the better outturn in Q3 may be hard to repeat. In addition, Food could also be in the firing line with its added-value offer. The last time we saw a decline in GDP along with sharply rising food price inflation was in FY09. Although of a different scale to today's outlook, M&S Food LFL declined by 5%. We think there are grounds to assume modestly negative Food LFL for the next two years, as well as some gross margin pressure. This results in a double digit EPS downgrade for FY19E and some increase in the risk profile.

BE11:15am

There are no changes to FY17 estimates. For FY18 we assume Food LFL declines by 0.5% (from flat) and gross margin declines by 10bp (from +10bp). There are no changes to FY18 apparel assumptions. For FY19 we assume Food LFL -1% and gross margin down a further 10bp. Apparel gross margin falls 20bp from flat as a result of FX pressures. There is no material add back from lower opex as we had already assumed an increase below 2% for both years. We move from above consensus to below. The main upside risk is self-help in apparel being more material than expected.

BE11:15am

Our consumer survey shows a weak balance of spending intentions for M&S, Next and Debenhams. At M&S, we already expect negative LFL for FY18, and, with management making all the right moves, we do not change estimates. However, our survey suggests upside risk is now more limited, while we also assume modest gross margin pressure inFY18 rolls into FY19 as FX remains unhelpful and mitigation may be tougher.
Despite a respectable FCF yield and an invigorated management team, it seems premature to expect either a rerating or positive earnings momentum in the foreseeable future. Our PT is based on DCF and falls with the estimate downgrades and related lower margins to perpetuity. We assume 2% terminal growth, 6.5% terminal margin (from 7%) and WACC of 8.5%.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

N Brown goes to "sell" for pretty much identical reasons. As in, old people clothes.

N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 208.75, down 7.75 (-3.58%), High: 211.00, Low: 205.25, Volume: 246.83k
undefined
11:15 am
PM11:16am

Hey, did we know Tom Albanese was leaving Vedanta?

PM11:16am

There were rumours of it a while back -- but those were denied

PM11:16am

I may have completely missed this

11:16 am
PM11:16am

But look at today's statement

PM11:16am

Vedanta Resources plc (the 'Company') announces that the Company has agreed to extend the Executive Service Agreement of its chief executive officer, Tom Albanese until 31 August 2017. Tom's three year contract was due to expire on 31 March 2017.

Mr Anil Agarwal, Vedanta's Executive Chairman and the chairman of the Nominations Committee, is leading the succession process to identify candidates with appropriate global experience and a further announcement will be made in due course.

PM11:17am

Headline:

11:16 am
PM11:17am

Extension of Executive Service Agreement for Tom Albanese

PM11:17am

Perhaps it should have read CEO to step down 3 months after contract ends

Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 801.05, up 11.05 (+1.40%), High: 812.50, Low: 794.50, Volume: 255.12k
11:18 am
PM11:18am

Perhaps the Rabble can update me on that

PM11:18am

Just seemed a very strange statement to me

BE11:19am

I'm not following closely enough, to be honest, but didn't Agarwal hire Cynthia Carroll in 2015 to help Albanese with "corporate strategy"?

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Yes, and this caused the departure rumour

PM11:19am

https://www.bloomb...rts-of-ceo-leaving

BE11:20am

Cynthia Carroll being ex Anglo, of course, which Agarwal's just done this weird stake purchase thing on.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Keep meaning to go back and look at that in detail

BE11:20am

There looks to be a gameplan here and I don't think I'm smart enough to figure it out.

BE11:21am

Anyway, have GS.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Noting not the management jiggery but the news that Vedanta India is paying a c.Rs17 divi.

BE11:22am

Which is a reason why they're up, albeit a dull one.

BE11:22am

$500m goes to Ved PLC.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

This is a positive for Vedanta Plc in our view. The company as of 1H17 had US$200 mn of debt maturities for FY17 which were to be repaid using the inter-company loan.
1. Of the US$500 mn being upstreamed a portion of it is likely to be declared as dividends: our estimate for the dividend this year is USc50/share, but we see upside risk to this.
2. The company has US$1bn of bank debt maturing in FY18. While these facilities could be repaid, Vedanta has been very pro-active in terming out its debt, so we do not see that as an imminent risk.
With the Cairn merger almost complete (approvals from RBI are the only ones now are needed), we believe that the market continues to underestimate the earnings potential / cash flow generation potential of the company. The recent share price weakness has been largely a function of a single share holder selling, in our view, plus general sentiment turning bearish towards the mining sector.
We highlight that the company has very little iron ore exposure (c.7% of FY18E EBITDA) while zinc, oil and aluminium form c.75% of the company’s EBITDA. We have a positive view on all these commodities and see upside from spot levels.

undefined
PM11:23am

This non-insider dealing case just out

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Have a read of this

BE11:23am

Oh, go on.

PM11:23am

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has today fined Christopher Niehaus, a former investment banker, £37,198 for sharing client confidential information over WhatsApp. The FCA found that Mr Niehaus failed to act with due skill, care and diligence.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

The FCA found that Mr Niehaus, who was a managing director in the Investment Banking division at Jefferies International Limited, received client confidential information during the course of his employment and, on a number of occasions between 24 January and 16 May 2016, shared that information with both a personal acquaintance and a friend, who was also a client of the firm. In one of the instances where Mr Niehaus shared client confidential information with his friend, who was also a client of the firm, that information was about a competitor. Mr Niehaus used the instant messaging application “WhatsApp” to share this information. The information was shared by Mr Niehaus because he wanted to impress the people that he shared the information with.

PM11:23am

The details of the information he shared included the identity of the client, the details relating to the client mandate and the fee Jefferies would charge for their involvement in the transaction. Mr Niehaus also boasted about how he may be able to pay off his mortgage if one of the deals was successful.

PM11:24am

And then this...

11:23 am
PM11:24am

Neither Mr Niehaus nor the individuals he shared the information with dealt in any securities relating to these disclosures and it is accepted that this information was not shared by Mr Niehaus with that expectation.

BE11:24am

Why's this a problem?

PM11:24am

I don't know

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Mr Niehaus was suspended from Jefferies pending the completion of its disciplinary process and he resigned before that process was completed.

BE11:25am

I mean, I don't really want my bank manager talking about my overdraft to his mates. But I'd not expect him to be sacked and fined for doing so.

PM11:25am

It's like if you told your partner in bed about a deal you were doing -- if they FCA were able to get proof, they'd fine you and ruin your careere

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Why don't they go after bad people instead???

BE11:26am

And the fact that it's over Whatsapp seems totally irrelevant. It's equivalent to saying he breached confidentiality agreements over a pint in the Dog and Duck ...

PM11:26am

hehhe -- i know!

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Clearly bankers shouldn't be allowed to have pints in the Dog and Duck.

BE11:26am

Bloody FCA.

PM11:01am

11:28 am

The larger question would be, "why?"

PM11:29am

Talking about European expansion i think

BE11:29am

But why does AO World need money? It has money.

11:29 am

It forecasts £27m on the balance sheet by year end.

BE11:30am

BE11:30am

So I guess we infer from this that it's not.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Or it needs more cash chucked at advertising.

PM11:31am

Ah, now here you might be on to something...

PM11:31am

Advertising wise

11:31 am
BE11:31am

...... Because all AO World has is advertising. That's an underappreciated flaw of the online-only model.

BE11:32am

You don't get walkthrough custom. You need to pull people to the site whenever they need a washing machine. And most people only need a washing machine once a decade, so a lot of the advertising points at people who'll never buy anything.

BE11:32am

Have some Shore.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Management has stated that it expects to see trading from the second half to continue into FY2018. We have previously stated we harbour concerns about the continued downward pressure being applied to estimates, demonstrating weak earnings momentum. The shares are currently trading on c75x our existing FY2018 EBITDA expectations. Prior to today, although we held a neutral stance, we indicated that we believed the pendulum swung more towards downside, rather than upside, to the current share price.

BE11:33am

Whilst we applaud management for building a strong consumer proposition, we downgrade our recommendation to a SELL, reflecting our concerns around:

Continued downward pressure to guidance (we will be revising our forecasts shortly)
The potential for possible cash burn ahead indicative of the need to raise capital
Possible softness in the consumer electricals market noting the significant price increase being pushed through by suppliers
The slowing growth rate of the business on an underlying basis in its core UK market.

BE11:33am

(@FATDAZ: Ashley's stake moving between counterparties I think.)

11:34 am
BE11:34am

And JP Morgan Caz.

BE11:35am

FY17 UK revenue is expected to increase by c.13% (JPMe +15%) to £629m. Whilst AO.com growth has accelerated in the final quarter to c.13% yoy (Q3 +10% yoy), this is below our expectations for +19%. In addition, the decline in third-party retail sales has accelerated. As flagged by management at the Q3 stage, the UK environment is tough and uncertain and we expect promotional activity to have increased yoy in the final quarter. Therefore, we reduce our FY17 UK EBITDA forecast by 6% from £24.8m to £23.4m. In terms of FX-driven inflation, we estimate that AO has increased prices by c.10% (in-line with the market), although we expect average selling prices to have risen by less than this given promotional activity. This would imply AO.com volume growth of mid-high single digit (which would represent good market share gains).

BE11:35am

(@Mouselet: it is -- though SEO's bloody expensive as well.)

11:35 am
AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 140.80, up 2.9 (+2.10%), High: 142.60, Low: 132.80, Volume: 201.26k
BE11:36am

Remarkably sanguine reaction to a warning that profits will be at the bottom of the range and it needs more money to burn on an entirely unproven expansion plan. Still, what do I know?

RPC mentioned on the right

PM11:38am

Pre close statement here: http://www.investe...1703300700099468A/

11:38 am
BE11:39am

PM11:39am

Paul Moran the analysts there

PM11:39am

38 pages on the matter Omg smile

11:39 am
BE11:39am

(I did my best to sum it all up here: https://www.ft.com...-b030-768954394623 ... your mileage may vary.)

BE11:40am

I guess, today, we get an attempt at reassurance that hasn't quite stuck.

BE11:40am

Here's Deutsche.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

FY-16-17E revenues are expected by RPC to be significantly ahead yoy based on contribution from acquisitions and continued underlying organic growth (+3% reported in H1 which we think has been sustained). Mgmt sees overall performance encouraging, with adj. op. profit in fact ahead of expectations.

BE11:41am

The recent GCS (completed Mar-16) and BPI (completed Aug-16) have been integrated well and are performing ahead of expectations, acc. to RPC. ESE (completed Jan 31) is expected to make a FY-16/17E contribution and early purchasing synergies have been realized. Letica (completed 10 March) has realized CY-16 EBITDA of USD67m as already reported in its trading update published along with closing (up from USD57m reported for LTM in H1), implying a 7.3x 2016 EV/EBITDA multiple (and thus much below the 8.5x initial headline, as mentioned). Astrapak is expected to be completed in June. RPC is stressing that the targets’ mgmt teams are being retained in most cases.

BE11:41am

We think mgmt statements of being ahead expectations imply that FY results could come in slightly ahead of DBe of GBP291m and Reuters est’s of GBP289m for adj. op. profit. We believe this is owed to earlier than expected closing of deals and swifter synergy realization and a strong outcome in light of continued mild polymer headwinds in H2. On organic growth, we feel 3% H1 run-rates should have been largely sustained in H2. Given slightly better FY-16/17 performance, on track deal integration and a strong trading update for Letica, we feel fine with our unchanged estimates for FY-17/18E, reflecting a roughly GBP100m adj. op. profit uplift. On the back of this, RPC trades on 8.6x 18/19E EV/EBITDA (incl. pensions), below 9.5x for plastic packaging peers.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Part of Northern Trust's argument was that RPC, because it does a lot of acquisitions, raises a lot of money.

BE11:42am

And appoints a lot of brokers.

BE11:42am

Those brokers all have buy recommendations on RPC.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Deutsche did a big defence of RPC after the Northern Trust stuff came out. Debbie Jones there must be a little peeved.

BE11:42am

Yep.

WebMD Health [NASDAQ:WBMD] recently reached out to potential suitors to invite them to participate in a sale process, three sources briefed on the matter said.

11:55 am

Trading up date http://www.investe...1703300700109493A/

PM11:56am

Clive Black still saying sell Booker

PM11:56am

But the statement is really strong, no?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Yep. Numbers are good as usual.

BE11:56am

And Tesco-Booker remains something investors need to be convinced about.

BE11:57am

Similar to Sainsbury-Argos, now I think about it. Except without the effective zero cost to the buyer via loan book clever stuff.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

What's Clive saying?

PM11:58am

A lot, as per ususal

PM11:58am

here's a bit of it

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Shareholder resistance & dissatisfactionBeyond the regulator, shareholders have also been active with respect to this proposed merger. We sense that many long-standing Booker investors have expressed their view by taking advantage of the stock mark-up following the merger announcement and ending their association with the company; a course that we advised was appropriate upon announcement of the merger, which still underpins our SELLstance on the group's shares. Equally, we believe that the market's reaction from a Tesco perspective is underwhelming too with the stock not holding any gains since the announcement,with one or two very highly respected and regarded institutional investors actually advocating disapproval of the merger.

PM11:58am

Tesco's preliminary results needs to change perceptionsTesco will have to present a more compelling case for this merger, we sense, than the very amateurish presentation pack for this still fine establishment that was produced at the time of the merger announcement, one which sadly was subject to much ridicule and comic appraisal inmany of our exchanges with the market in subsequent weeks. We sense that results session will be the next threshold of a process that has some months to run. It is fair to say in our viewthat at first base all could be a lot better and this is not a slam dunk deal. This being the case, given it is not a transformational deal for Tesco forus, we are reasonably relaxed from its shareholder's perspective; whilst we still need a lot more convincing to recommend acceptance of the deal, we remain open to some more compelling persuasion.

PM11:58am

And to summarise

11:58 am
PM11:59am

SELL stance on Booker reiteratedSo, in conclusion, today's (30th March 2017) Q4 trading statement certainly does not suggest that Charles Wilson, someone for which we have enormous respect and admiration, has lost his focus on the day job; we did think he would though. However, as we have sought to articulate above, today's update is not really what Booker's investment thesis is about anymore. Accordingly, on reflection, with this update in tow, we reiterate our original thoughts of the merger with a cautious and still uncertain commentary and our SELL stance on Booker's shares

undefined

BE12:01pm
